title: Peter O'Rourke
text:
Peter O'Rourke (1 June 1873 – 10 January 1956) was a Scottish <a href="association%20football">football</a> player and <a href="manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a>. In two spells as manager of <a href="Bradford%20City%20A.F.C.">Bradford City</a>, he won the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> in <a href="1911%20FA%20Cup%20Final">1911</a> as well as two league titles, the <a href="Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Football League Second Division</a> in <a href="1907%E2%80%9308%20Football%20League">1908</a> and the <a href="Football%20League%20Third%20Division%20North">Third Division North</a> in <a href="1928%E2%80%9329%20Football%20League">1929</a>.
Career.
O'Rourke was a <a href="defender%20%28football%29">centre half</a> who played for <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a>, <a href="Burnley%20F.C.">Burnley</a>, <a href="Lincoln%20City%20F.C.">Lincoln City</a>, <a href="Third%20Lanark">Third Lanark</a> and <a href="Chesterfield%20F.C.">Chesterfield</a> before his final playing days at <a href="Bradford%20City%20A.F.C.">Bradford City</a>. He became player-manager in 1905 following the departure of <a href="Robert%20Campbell%20%28football%20manager%29">Robert Campbell</a> while he was still captain. He was given the job permanently and in December 1905 played his final game in an <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> tie against <a href="Darlington%20F.C.">Darlington</a>.
He led the Bantams to the <a href="Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Second Division</a> championship in 1908. Three years later, O'Rourke clinched the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> with Bradford in 1911, beating <a href="Newcastle%20United">Newcastle United</a> 1–0 in a replay. His son, Francis, died in Newfoundland in October 1919, affecting him deeply, and in June 1921, due to ill health, O'Rourke retired from the game.
He came back with Welsh side <a href="Pontypridd%20Town%20A.F.C.">Pontypridd</a> in 1922 for five months. In December of that year, O'Rourke joined <a href="Dundee%20United%20F.C.">Dundee Hibernian</a>, who were then a non-league club, but stayed for only three months, resigning after lacking financial support. His next managerial job was with <a href="Bradford%20%28Park%20Avenue%29%20A.F.C.">Bradford Park Avenue</a> from 1924 to 1925. He spent just ten months at Park Avenue but signed another son, <a href="Peter%20O%27Rourke%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201903%29">Peter</a>, who scored twice on his debut against <a href="Durham%20City%20F.C.">Durham City</a>.
He returned to Bradford City in 1928, winning the <a href="Third%20Division%20North">Third Division North</a> the following year. After leaving Bradford for the second time in 1930, he moved to Walsall, before a final managerial spell with <a href="Llanelli%20A.F.C.">Llanelli</a>. He retired in July 1933.
After retiring, O'Rourke returned to Bradford living in Burlington Terrace next to City's <a href="Valley%20Parade">Valley Parade</a> ground until he died in January 1956 at the age of 82.
Honours.
Manager.
Bradford City
